oai_dc:dc.dc:title: A river landing scene
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four men, three of them African American, load and unload goods at a river landing. The men are using a gangplank to access the riverboat. One man holds chickens and a package in his hand. A riverboat captain stands in the background.

"Roustabouts" were the men who handled cargo on the commercial steamboats that plied Southern rivers after the Civil War. Many worked at the river landings where the boats made stops. Riverboats were indispensable for Southern commerce by hauling passengers and freight from one point to another.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: African Americans; Men; Waterfronts
